mainlistitem.title: Unit 1: Where do you come from?

lessonitem.title: Lesson A
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: Good morning, Max. How are you today? Max: Fine, thank you. And you? Kathy: Just fine. Hello, everyone. My name is Kathy. I come from New York. Max: New York? Kathy: Yes, New York. Where do you come from, Max? Max: I come from San Francisco. Kathy: San Francisco? Max: That's right. San Francisco, California.

lessonitem.title: Lesson B
lessonitem.viewscript: Wu: Hello. Kathy: Hello. Wu: My name is Wu Hongli. I come from China. Kathy: From China? Wu: That's right. I come from China. I have a question for you. Kathy: Yes. What is it? Wu: Do you come from New York City or New York state? Kathy: I come from New York City. And New York City is in New York state. May I ask you a question? Wu: OK. Kathy: What city do you come from, Mr. Wu? Wu: What city? I come from Beijing. Kathy: You come from Beijing? Wu: Yes, I come from Beijing.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0101B_Q1.mp3|Does Mr. Wu come from China?
NDE0101B_Q2.mp3|Who comes from New York City?
NDE0101B_Q3.mp3|What city does Mr. Wu come from?

grammaritem.answer: Do you come from New York?

lessonitem.title: Lesson C
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: Now let's check our email. We have an e-mail from Susan Shaw in Chicago. Max, she has a question for you. Her question is: Do you come from Los Angeles? Max: Do I come from Los Angeles? No, I don't. I come from San Francisco. I don't come from Los Angeles.

comprehensionitem.question: Does Max come from Los Angeles?
Does Max come from San Francisco?

lessonitem.title: Lesson A
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Robert Harris. Good morning, Mr. Harris. Bob: Good morning, Kathy. Please call me Bob. Kathy: OK, Bob. I have a question for you. Bob: Please, go ahead. Kathy: OK. Where are you from? Bob: I'm from Florida. Disney World is in Florida. Kathy: Is Disney World in Miami? Bob: No, it's not. It's in Orlando. Orlando, Florida. Kathy: Are you from Orlando? Bob: No, I'm not. I'm not from Orlando. I'm from Miami.

comprehensionitem.question: Where does Bob Harris come from?

lessonitem.title: Lesson B
lessonitem.viewscript: Khalid: My name is Khalid. I come from Cairo. Kathy: You come from Egypt? Khalid: That's right. I come from Egypt. Cairo is the capital of Egypt. I have a question for Mr. Harris. Bob: Yes. What is it? Khalid: You come from Florida. Is Memphis in Florida? Bob: No, it's not. It's in Tennessee.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0102B_Q2.mp3|What is the capital of Egypt?

grammaritem.answer: Cairo is the capital of Egypt.

lessonitem.title: Lesson C
lessonitem.viewscript: Khalid: Ahh, I have another question. Bob: Yes? Khalid: Is Max from Florida? Bob: No, he isn't. He's from California. Khalid: California? Bob: That's right. He's from California. Khalid: Oh. Thank you.

comprehensionitem.question: Who isn't from the United States?

lessonitem.title: Lesson A
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: Our guests today are Sara Scott and her sister. Good morning, Sara. Max: Hi, Sara. Sara: Good morning, Kathy. Hello, Max. Kathy: Thank you for coming. Sara: Thank you for inviting me. Kathy, I'd like to introduce my sister, Chris. Kathy: Hello, Chris. Nice to meet you. Chris: Hello, Kathy. It's nice to meet you too. Max: Hello, Chris. Chris: Hello, Max. Nice to meet you. Kathy: OK, Sara. I'd like to ask you a question. Sara: Certainly. Kathy: What city do you come from? Sara: I come from Chicago.

lessonitem.title: Lesson B
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: What city do you come from? Sara: I come from Chicago. Kathy: Chris, are you from Chicago too? Chris: Yes, I'm from Chicago. Sara and I are both from Chicago. Sara: Yes, we're both from Chicago. Max: I'm from San Francisco. Chris: Really? I love San Francisco! The Golden Gate Bridge is in San Francisco. Max: That's right. What's in Chicago? Sara: Well, the Sears Tower is in Chicago. Chris: And the Chicago Bulls basketball team is in Chicago. Kathy: I love basketball!

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0103B_Q1.mp3|Where are Sara and Chris from?
NDE0103B_Q2.mp3|Is the Golden Gate Bridge in Chicago?

grammaritem.answer: What city do you come from?

lessonitem.title: Lesson C
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: Let's look at our e-mail. Kathy: We have a message from Kim in Korea. Her question is: Where is Chicago? Sara, where is Chicago? Sara: Well, it's in the United States. It's in Illinois... in the state of Illinois. It's between New York and San Francisco. Kathy: Sara, Chris, thank you for being on our show. Max: Yes, thank you. Sara: Thank you for inviting us.

comprehensionitem.question: Is Chicago in the United States?
Is Chicago between New York and San Francisco?

grammaritem.question: Chicago is _____ New York and San Francisco.

lessonitem.title: Lesson Bonus
lessonitem.viewscript: Kent: This is the New Dynamic English Man on the Street, Kent Moss. Today I'm standing in front of the Capitol Building in Washington, D.C. Excuse me, sir? Henry: Yes? Kent: I'd like to ask you a few questions. Henry: OK, go ahead. Kent: What's your name? Henry: My name is Henry Parker. Kent: And where are you from? Henry: I'm from Tallahassee. Kent: Tallahassee? Henry: Yes, Tallahassee. Kent: Where is Tallahassee? Henry: It's in Florida. Tallahassee is in Florida. Kent: Is that a Spanish name? Henry: No, it's an Indian name. Kent: From India? Henry: No, American Indian. Kent: Really? Henry: Yes, some American cities have Indian names. Kent: Some American cities have Spanish names, like Los Angeles and San Francisco. Henry: That's right. Kent: And a lot of names come from England, like New York and New Hampshire. Henry: American names come from all over the world. Kent: That's right Well, thank you very much for talking with me. Henry: You're very welcome.

comprehensionitem.question: Where does the name Tallahassee come from?
Which of these American cities has a Spanish name?

grammaritem.question: Thank you very much ___________ with me.

lessonitem.title: Lesson A
lessonitem.viewscript: Max: What's that, Kathy? Kathy: Oh, that's a map of Europe. Today's guest comes from Europe. Max: Oh, what's his name? Kathy: His name is Pierre Dubois. Max: Where does he come from? Kathy: He's from France. Max: Let's look at that map again. Kathy: OK. Oh, look. Here's Florence. Max: Where? Kathy: Here. In Italy. Max: I see. Where's Rome? Kathy: It's here. Max: Where's Salzburg? Is Salzburg in Germany? Kathy: No, it's not. It's here. It's in Austria. Max: Really? I see. It is in Austria.

lessonitem.title: Lesson B
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: Pierre, I have a question for you. Pierre: Please. Kathy: You're French, right? Pierre: Yes, that's right. I'm from France. Max: Do you come from Paris? Pierre: Yes, I'm from Paris. Kathy: I love Paris. The Eiffel Tower is in Paris. Max: And the Prado Museum is in Paris too, right? Pierre: No. The Prado Museum isn't in Paris. It's in Madrid. The Louvre Museum is in Paris. Max: Oh, that's right.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0104B_Q1.mp3|What city does Pierre come from?

grammaritem.answer: The Prado Museum isn't in Paris.

lessonitem.title: Lesson C
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: Now it's time to read our e-mail. We have an e-mail today from Michael in Los Angeles, California. He writes: "I like Dijon mustard." "Does Dijon mustard come from France?" Max: Pierre, does Dijon mustard come from France? Pierre: Yes, it does. Dijon is a city in France. Kathy: I like cayenne pepper. Is Cayenne in France? Pierre: No, it's not. It's in South America. Kathy: I see.

comprehensionitem.question: Where does Dijon mustard come from?
Is Cayenne a city in France?

grammaritem.question: Pierre _____ come from the United States.
Dijon mustard _____ a city in France.

lessonitem.title: Lesson A
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Maria Alvarez. Good morning, Ms. Alvarez. Maria: Good morning. Please call me Maria. Kathy: OK. Maria, where do you come from? Maria: I come from San Jose. Kathy: San Jose, California? Maria: That's right. San Jose, California. Kathy: Your name is Spanish, isn't it? Maria: Yes, that's right. Alvarez is a Spanish name. My parents come from Mexico. Max: Do you speak Spanish? Maria: Yes, I do. I speak Spanish and English. Kathy: Me too. I speak English and Spanish. Max, do you speak Spanish? Max: No, I don't. I don't speak Spanish.

lessonitem.title: Lesson B
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Maria Alvarez. She comes from San Jose, California. Her parents come from Mexico. Maria, do your parents speak Spanish? Maria: Yes, they do. My mother speaks Spanish and English. Kathy: Does your father speak English? Maria: Yes, a little. He usually speaks Spanish.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0105B_Q1.mp3|Where do Maria's parents come from?
NDE0105B_Q3.mp3|What language does Maria's father usually speak?

lessonitem.title: Lesson C
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: We have time for a telephone call. Hello. You're on the air with New Dynamic English! Caller: Hello. My name is Bit. I'm from Thailand. I have a question for Maria. Maria: Yes, go ahead. Caller: You're from California, right? Maria: Yes, that's right. Caller: In California, do people speak Spanish? Maria: That's a good question. Some people in California speak Spanish. Many people in California speak both Spanish and English. Kathy: Bit, I have a question for you. Bit: Ahh, for me? Ahh, okay. Kathy: Do people in Thailand speak English? Caller: In Thailand, people speak Thai, but some people also speak English. Kathy: I see. Thank you.

comprehensionitem.question: Do some people in California speak Spanish?
Do people in Thailand speak English?

lessonitem.title: Lesson A
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: Our guests today are Pat Miller and Sandy Steele. Welcome to New Dynamic English. Sandy: Thank you. We're happy to be here. Kathy: Now, who is Sandy and who is Pat? Sandy: I'm Sandy. Pat: And I'm Pat. Nice to meet you, Kathy. Sandy: Yes, it's nice to be here. Kathy: Sandy, Pat, do you both come from the U.S.? Sandy: No, we don't. I come from the U.S., but Pat comes from Canada. Pat: That's right. I'm from Montreal. Montreal, Canada. But we both live in the U.S. We're students at American University. Kathy: Here in Washington, D.C.? Pat: Yes, that's right.

comprehensionitem.question: Is Sandy a man or a woman?
Who comes from Canada, Sandy or Pat?
Where do Sandy and Pat live?

grammaritem.question: Sandy comes from the U.S., ______ Pat comes from Canada.
Sandy and Pat both ________ in the United States.
They ________ both students at American University.

lessonitem.title: Lesson B
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: Where do you come from, Sandy? Sandy: Texas. I come from Dallas, Texas. Kathy: Pat, in Montreal, do people speak French? Pat: Yes, they do. People speak French in Montreal. Kathy: Do you speak French? Pat: Yes, I do. I speak French and English. Kathy: How about you, Sandy? Do you speak French? Sandy: No, I don't. I speak English and a little Spanish. ... but I don't speak French.

lessonitem.title: Lesson C
lessonitem.viewscript: Caller: Hello. My name is Samantha. I'm from Denver. Kathy: Yes, go ahead. Caller: Sandy, Pat. Which one of you is from Canada? Pat: I am. I'm from Canada. Caller: OK. I have a question for you. Pat: Yes.... Caller: People speak French in Montreal, right? Pat: Yes, that's right. Caller: Do people speak English in Montreal? Pat: That's a good question. In Montreal many people speak both French and English. Caller: I see. Thank you.

comprehensionitem.question: Pat is from Canada, isn't she?
Do many people in Montreal speak English?
Do all Canadian people speak French?

grammaritem.question: Pat _____ Montreal, and Sandy comes from Texas.
Pat and Sandy both live _____ Washington, D.C.
Sandy speaks English and a little Spanish, but he _____ speak French.

lessonitem.title: Lesson Bonus
lessonitem.viewscript: Kent: This is the New Dynamic English Man on the Street, Kent Moss. Today I'm standing in a children's playground in Washington, D.C. Excuse me? Barbara: Yes? Kent: Are these your children? Barbara: My children? Well, yes and no. I'm not their mother. But I do take care of them. I'm a childcare worker. Kent: Oh, I see. Barbara: Their parents are diplomats. They come from all over the world. Kent: Oh, they're so cute! Barbara: Yes, aren't they? Ying is from China. Mohammed is from Saudi Arabia. Hans and Krista come from Germany. And Michael is from Sierra Leone. Kent: Sierra Leone. Where's that? Barbara: It's in Africa. Kent: I see. Do they all speak English? Barbara: Yes, they do. They speak English as a second language. Ying speaks Chinese and English. Mohammed speaks Arabic and English. Hans and Krista speak German and English. And Michael speaks English and French. Kent: Do you speak all those languages? Barbara No, I don't. I only speak English. Oh excuse me! Hans, come back here! Hans, Hans... I have to go! Kent: OK. Nice talking to you.

comprehensionitem.question: Do the children speak English?
comprehensionitem.option: Some of them do; some of them don't.

comprehensionitem.question: What languages does the woman speak?

lessonitem.title: Lesson A
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: Our guest is Richard Chen. Good morning, Mr. Chen. Welcome to New Dynamic English. Richard: Thank you. Please call me Richard. Kathy: OK. Please call me Kathy. Richard: OK, Kathy. Kathy: You're the Teacher of the Year. Congratulations. Richard: Thank you. Kathy: What do you teach? Richard: I teach science and math. Kathy: Do you like it? Richard: Yes, I do. I love teaching.

comprehensionitem.question: Does Richard like his job?
comprehensionitem.option: Sometimes he does. Sometimes he doesn't.

lessonitem.title: Lesson B
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: Richard, tell us a little about your family. Richard: Well, I'm married and I have one child. Kathy: A boy or a girl? Richard: He's a boy. Kathy: What's his name? Richard: His name is Jason. Kathy: How old is he? Richard: He's five years old. Kathy: What's your wife's name? Richard: Her name is Jenny. Kathy: Jenny? Richard: That's right. Jenny. She and I both come from Hong Kong. Kathy: Thank you, Richard.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0107B_Q2.mp3|How many children does Richard have?

lessonitem.title: Lesson C
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: We're back with Richard Chen. He's married and has one son. Richard, some of our listeners have questions for you. Let's take a telephone call. Hello. You're on the air with New Dynamic English. Rachel: Hello. My name is Rachel. I'm from New Orleans. I have a question for Richard. Richard: Yes, go ahead. Rachel: I have three daughters in my family. Do you have any daughters? Richard: No, I don't have any daughters. I have one child, a son. Rachel: I see. Does your boy go to school? Richard: Yes, he does. He's in kindergarten. Rachel: Does he like school? Richard: Yes, he does. He loves his teacher. Rachel: I see. Thank you. Kathy: Thank you for calling.

comprehensionitem.question: How many daughters does Richard have?
Does Richard's son go to school?

lessonitem.title: Lesson A
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Sara Scott. Good morning, Sara. Sara: Good morning, Kathy. Nice to see you again. Kathy: It's nice to see you too. Welcome back to our show. Sara: I'm happy to be here. Kathy: Sara, I have a question for you. Sara: Yes? Kathy: You're from Chicago? Sara: That's right. I'm from Chicago. Kathy: What do you do in Chicago? What kind of job do you have? Sara: I'm a doctor. Kathy: A doctor? Sara: Yes, I work in a hospital. I work in a large hospital in Chicago. Kathy: Do you like your work? Sara: Yes, I do. I work hard but I like it.

comprehensionitem.question: Where does she work?
comprehensionitem.option: in a hospital outside of Chicago

grammaritem.question: What kind of job do you _____?

lessonitem.title: Lesson B
lessonitem.viewscript: Kristen: Hello. My name is Kristen. I'm from Massachusetts. Kathy: What city are you from? Kristen: I'm from Boston. I have a question for Sara. Sara: I'm listening. Kristen: I work in Boston but I don't live in the city. I live outside of the city, in the suburbs. Boston is a very expensive city. Max: What's your question? Kristen: You work in Chicago. Do you live in Chicago? Sara: Yes, I do.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0108B_Q3.mp3|Where does Sara live and work?

grammaritem.answer: Boston is a very expensive city.

lessonitem.title: Lesson C
lessonitem.viewscript: Kristen: Where do you live? Sara: I live in an apartment building. Kristen: Do you live alone? Sara: No, I don't. I live with my sister. Kristen: Is your apartment big? Sara: Yes, it is. It's big. Unfortunately, it's also expensive. Kristen: Expensive? Is it very expensive? Sara: Yes, it is. But it's very large and comfortable. Kristen: That's nice.

comprehensionitem.question: What is her apartment like?
comprehensionitem.option: It's very big, but it's expensive.
It's big, and not very expensive.
It's not very large or comfortable.
comprehensionitem.answer: It's very big, but it's expensive.

grammaritem.question: The apartment is very large and ___________.

lessonitem.title: Lesson A
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Henry Thornton. Good morning, Mr. Thornton. Henry: Good morning, Kathy. Kathy: Mr. Thornton, I'd like to ask you a question. Henry: Yes. Kathy: What do you do? Henry: What do I do? I'm a businessman. Kathy: Where do you work? I mean, who do you work for? Henry: I work for myself. I have my own company. Kathy: What's the name of your company? Henry: It's Titanic Limited. Kathy: Titanic? How do you spell that? Henry: T-I-T-A-N-I-C. Like the ship. Kathy: What do you do? Henry: What do I do? I'm the president. Kathy: The president? Henry: Yes, I'm the president of my company.

comprehensionitem.question: Who does Henry work for?
comprehensionitem.option: He works for his own company.
He works for a shipping company.
comprehensionitem.answer: He works for his own company.

comprehensionitem.question: What is the name of Henry's company?
What is Henry's position at the company?

lessonitem.title: Lesson B
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: Where is your company located? Henry: It's in Seattle. Kathy: Do you live in Seattle? Henry: Yes, I do. Kathy: With your family? Henry: Well, my mother and father live in Seattle. But I don't live with them! Kathy: Where do you live? Henry: I live in a large house. A very expensive house!

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0109B_Q2.mp3|Does Henry live with his parents??

grammaritem.answer: My mother and father live in Seattle.
I don't live with my parents.

lessonitem.title: Lesson C
lessonitem.viewscript: Caller: Hello. My name is Susan. I'm from Boston. I have a question for Mr. Thornton. Henry: Yes, go ahead. Caller: Are you married? Henry: Excuse me? Caller: Are you married? Henry: No. No, I'm not. Caller: Do you live alone? Henry: Yes, I do. Caller: No wife? No girlfriend? Henry: That's right. But I do have a lot of money. Caller: Well, good luck.

grammaritem.question: Henry _______ in a very expensive house.

lessonitem.title: Lesson Bonus
lessonitem.viewscript: Kent: This is the New Dynamic English Man on the Street, Kent Moss. Today I'm standing on Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington, D.C. Excuse me, sir? Man: Yes. Kent: I'd like to ask you a few questions. Man: Why? Kent: This is for the New Dynamic English radio show. Man: Oh, I see. OK, go ahead. Kent: Can you tell our listeners what you do? Man: What do I do? I'm a painter. Kent: A painter? So, do you paint pictures? Man: No, I paint houses. Kent: Do you like your work? Man: Yes, I do. I like painting big houses for important people. Kent: You have a lot of white paint in your truck. Man: That's right. Right now, I'm painting that big white house across the street. Kent: That big white house? Man: That's right. Kent: Do you mean...? That house belongs to the President! That's theWhite House. Man: That's right. And it does need painting! Kent: I see. Well, thank you very much. Man: You're very welcome.

comprehensionitem.question: What color paint does the man have in his truck?
Who lives in the White House?
comprehensionitem.option: the President of the United States
comprehensionitem.answer: the President of the United States

grammaritem.question: I like __________ houses for important people.

mainlistitem.title: Unit 10: My wife's name is Sandra.

lessonitem.title: Lesson A
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Robert Harris. Welcome back, Bob. Bob: Hi, Kathy. Hi, Max. Nice to see you again. Max: Good to see you again, Bob. Kathy: Bob, you're married, aren't you? Bob: Yes, I am. Kathy: What's your wife's name? Bob: Her name is Sandra. Kathy: What does she do? Bob: She's a music teacher. She teaches piano. Kathy: Where does she work? Bob: She works at home.

lessonitem.title: Lesson B
lessonitem.viewscript: Bob: She's a music teacher. She teaches piano. Kathy: Where does she work? Bob: She works at home. Kathy: In your home? Bob: Yes, we have a small house in Miami. Her students come to our house. Kathy: I see. Do you have any children? Bob: Yes, we do. We have two children, a girl and a boy. Kathy: What are their names? Bob: Collette and John. Our daughter's name is Collette, and our son's name is John.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0110B_Q2.mp3|How many children do Bob and Sandra have?

grammaritem.answer: We have a small house in Miami.

lessonitem.title: Lesson C
lessonitem.viewscript: Michelle: Hello. My name is Michelle. I'm from San Diego. Kathy: Hello, Michelle. Michelle: I'd like to ask Mr. Harris a question. Bob: Yes, what is it? Michelle: What do you do? Where do you work? Bob: I work at the post office. Michelle: At the post office? Bob: Yes. I'm a postal worker. Michelle: Do you like your work? Bob: Ah... sometimes I do, sometimes I don't. And unfortunately my salary is low. Michelle: Do you work hard? Bob: Oh, yes, I work very hard.

comprehensionitem.question: What does Bob do?
comprehensionitem.option: He works at the post office.
comprehensionitem.answer: He works at the post office.

comprehensionitem.question: Does he like his work?
comprehensionitem.option: Sometimes he does; sometimes he doesn't.
comprehensionitem.answer: Sometimes he does; sometimes he doesn't.

comprehensionitem.question: Is his salary high or low?

lessonitem.title: Lesson A
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Chris Scott. Good morning, Chris. Chris: Hi, Kathy. Hello, Max. Thanks for having me back. Kathy: Our pleasure. Max: It's nice to see you again. Kathy: Where's your sister today? Where's Sara? Chris: She's in Baltimore. She's at Johns Hopkins Hospital. Max: Is she sick? Chris: No, she isn't. She's a doctor. She likes to visit hospitals. Max: That's right. She's a doctor.

comprehensionitem.question: Is Sara sick?
comprehensionitem.option: She is visiting a sick friend.

lessonitem.title: Lesson B
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: What do you do, Chris? Chris: I'm a dancer. Kathy: A dancer? Chris: Yes, a ballet dancer. Kathy: Really? Do you like it? Chris: Oh, I love it! I love to dance. Kathy: Do you work hard? Chris: Yes, I do. I practice every day. I want to be a great dancer.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0111B_Q1.mp3|What does Chris do?
comprehensionitem.option: She likes to go to dance clubs.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0111B_Q2.mp3|How does she feel about dancing?

grammaritem.answer: I want to be a great dancer.

lessonitem.title: Lesson C
lessonitem.viewscript: Helen: Who is older, you or your sister? Chris: My sister is older. She's twenty-eight years old. Helen: How old are you? Chris: I'm twenty-four years old. Helen: You're both single, aren't you? Chris: That's right. My sister has a boyfriend. He's a pilot. He's really cute! Helen: What about you? Chris: Well, my best friend is Woody. Helen: Woody? Is he your boyfriend? Chris: No, he isn't. He's not my boyfriend. He's my dog. Helen: Your dog? Chris: Yes, he's my pet dog. I love him!

comprehensionitem.question: How old is Chris's sister?
comprehensionitem.option: She's the same age as Chris.

grammaritem.question: Who is _______, you or your sister?

mainlistitem.title: Unit 12: Do you like your job?

lessonitem.title: Lesson A
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Maria Alvarez. Good morning, Maria. Maria: Good morning, Kathy. Kathy: Yes, welcome back to our show. Maria: Thank you. Kathy: I have a question for you. Maria: Yes, what is it? Kathy: What do you do? Maria: I'm a store manager. Kathy: A store manager? Maria: Yes, that's right. I manage a clothing store. Kathy: Is it a large store? Maria: Yes, it is. Kathy: Where is it? Where is it located? Maria: In San Jose. It's in downtown San Jose. Kathy: Is the clothing expensive? Maria: No, not really. Most of our clothes are not very expensive

comprehensionitem.question: Does the store sell expensive clothing?
comprehensionitem.option: Most of the clothes are expensive.
All of the clothes are expensive.
Most of the clothes are not very expensive.
comprehensionitem.answer: Most of the clothes are not very expensive.

grammaritem.question: Most of our clothes _______ not expensive.

lessonitem.title: Lesson B
lessonitem.viewscript: Kathy: Do you like your work? Maria: Yes, I do. It's a very good job. I like it a lot. Kathy: What about your salary? Do you have a good salary? Maria: It's pretty high, but I work very hard. Kathy: How many hours do you work? Maria: I work about 10 hours a day. Kathy: You do work hard! Maria: Yes, but I love the work!

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0112B_Q2.mp3|How many hours a day does she work?
NDE0112B_Q3.mp3|Does she enjoy the work?
comprehensionitem.option: It's hard but she likes it.
comprehensionitem.answer: It's hard but she likes it.

grammaritem.answer: Do you have a good salary?
How many hours do you work?
I work about 10 hours a day.

lessonitem.title: Lesson C
lessonitem.viewscript: Caller: Maria. Could you tell us about your family? Maria: Well, I'm divorced, and I have three children. Caller: Do they live with you? Maria: Yes, they do. Caller: What are their names? Maria: Alma, Josh, and Ehren. Caller: Excuse me? Could you say that again? Maria: Certainly. Alma..., Josh... and Ehren. Caller: Ehren? How do you spell Ehren? Maria: It's E-H-R-E-N. Caller: E-A-R-E-N? Maria: No... E - H- R - E - N. Caller: Oh, I see. That's a very pretty name. Maria: Thank you. Caller: Is Ehren a boy or a girl? Maria: She's a girl. My son's name is Josh. Caller: I see. How old are your children? Maria: Alma is twelve, Josh is seven, and Ehren is three. Caller: Twelve, seven, and three. Maria: That's right.

comprehensionitem.question: How many children does she have?

lessonitem.title: Lesson Bonus
lessonitem.viewscript: Kent: This is the New Dynamic English Man on the Street, Kent Moss. Today I'm standing in front of the Washington Monument in Washington D.C. Kent: That was beautiful! Man: Thank you very much. Kent: Do you play here every day? Man: Yes, I do. I play here in the afternoon before I go to work. Kent: Where do you work? Man: At a restaurant near here. Kent: What do you do? Man: I'm a waiter. Kent: A waiter? Do you like your job? Man: Oh, it's OK. And the pay is good. But I really love playing music. Kent: Well, you're an excellent musician. Man: Thank you. I don't make much money playing music, but I love it. My girlfriend's also a musician. Kent: Oh, what does she play? Man: She plays the flute. I play the violin and she plays the flute. We make beautiful music together. Kent: Well, I wish both of you the best of luck. Man: Thank you. Would you like to hear some more? Kent: Please...

comprehensionitem.question: How does he feel about playing music?
comprehensionitem.option: He wants to be a waiter.

grammaritem.question: I play here in the afternoon _________ I go to work.
I don't make ______ money playing music.
I play the violin and she ________ the flute.
